tatami.core.agent.claim

Class ClaimBehavior

  • java.lang.Object
    • Behaviour
      • tatami.core.agent.claim.ClaimBehavior
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AgentGui.InputListener

    public class ClaimBehavior
extends Behaviour
implements AgentGui.InputListener
    There is one ClaimBehavior instance for each behavior in a ClaimAgent.
    Author:
    Nguyen Thi Thuy Nga, Andrei Olaru

      • handleReceive

        protected boolean handleReceive(java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> args,
                    ClaimBehaviorDefinition myBehavior)
        Handle the receive construct.

        Format: (receive field-1 field-2 ...)

        Fields that are values or instantiated variables are used to match the received message; uninstantiated variables will be bound to the values in the message

        Parameters:
        args - : the arguments of the construct - the fields
        Returns:
        true if the received message matches the pattern (the behavior should continue); false otherwise

      • handleInput

        protected boolean handleInput(java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> args)
        There are two mechanisms for handling input:

        For active inputs, the input will call the receiveInput() method of the behavior. The arguments will be stored in the input queue of the input, and in this method will be copied to the elements in the construct.

        For passive inputs, the behavior will use getInput to get the arguments of the input, which will be copied to the elements in the construct.

        The difference between active and passive inputs is done by looking if there are any events in the queue of the input. If there are, the input is active and is not queried for arguments. Otherwise, the input is passive.

        The behavior will only be immediately activated by an active input (that restarts the behavior in receiveInput().

      • handleOutput

        protected boolean handleOutput(java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> args)

      • handleForAllK

        protected void handleForAllK(ClaimForAllK construct,
                 KnowledgeBase knowledgeBase)
        Read all records of knowledge in the knowledge base that match the pattern. Used in forAllK function.

        - First, check if knowledge type matches.

        - If matches, bind variable in knowledge pattern that haven't been bound by the value of knowledge in the knowledge base that has the same type.

        - If there's any field that doesn't match, the pattern doesn't match.

        Execute the statements inside the forAllK after binding all variables

        Parameters:
        construct - : the construct of forAllK - Structure of knowledge :

        "forAllK((struct knowledge <knowledge Type> <knowledge field 1..n >) <statements> )"

        knowledge - : the knowledge base

      • readMessage

        protected boolean readMessage(ClaimStructure messageStructure,
                  java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> args)
        Read a received message. Content of the message is in the form of a claim structure
        Parameters:
        messageStructure - : structure received in message : (struct message f1 f2 f3 ... fn)
        args - : vector of ClaimConstruct (defined in adf2) : f1 f2 f3 ... fn

      • readStructure

        protected boolean readStructure(ClaimStructure sourceStructure,
                    ClaimStructure destinationStructure,
                    int ignore,
                    boolean mandatoryMatch,
                    boolean rebindAllowed)
        The function has two goals: match the source and destination structures based on their structure and values; and instantiate variables in the destination structure based on the values in the source structure.

        If the destination field is a value, or an instantiated variable, it is checked if it matches the value of the source.

        If the destination field is an uninstantiated variable, it will be instanced to the value of the corresponding source field.

        If both destination and source field are structures, the function is called recursively.

        Parameters:
        sourceStructure -
        destinationStructure -
        ignore - : number of fields at the beginning to ignore in both structures
        mandatoryMatch - : states if it is mandatory to have a match before binding the fields of the destination
        rebindAllowed - : set to true to allow variables to be rebound; PLEASE do this only for Java calls; FIXME: this is only allowed for re-assignable variables, which will always be reassignable. Therefore, this parameter should be eliminated.
        Returns:
        true if the two structures match.

      • readValues

        protected boolean readValues(java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> sourceConstructs,

      • readStructure

        protected boolean readStructure(ClaimStructure sourceStructure,
                    ClaimStructure destinationStructure,
                    int ignore,
                    boolean mandatoryMatch,
                    boolean rebindAllowed,
                    java.util.Map<ClaimVariable,ClaimValue> bindingsOut)
        see the other definition of readStructure() for details. This version only returns the bindings to be done, does not actually do the bindings.
        Parameters:
        bindingsOut - : the map will be filled with the bindings to perform.

      • flattenConstructs

        protected java.util.Vector<ClaimConstruct> flattenConstructs(java.util.List<ClaimConstruct> constructs,
                                                 int ignore,
                                                 ClaimBehavior.KeepVariables keepVariables)
        Converts a List of ClaimConstruct instances - presumably from a larger construct or a structure - to a Vector of constructs with only values or some variables (see below).
        Parameters:
        constructs - : the constructs to transform to values
        ignore - : number of leading constructs to ignore (e.g. 'knowledge', 'message', etc)
        keepVariables - : what to do with variables: transform to values (or null, if uninstantiated); keep only uninstantiated variables (with the purpose of instantiating them); or keep all variables (with the purpose of changing their value).
        Returns:
        the values of the constructs or uninstantiated variables

        protected ClaimValue getVariableValue(ClaimVariable variable)
        Get value of variable from the symbol table. First, search the variable in behavior's symbol table. If not found, search in agent's symbol table
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        : Value of variable if found; null otherwise
